You should be surprised that with only 54 hours in a game like this, I can tell you that I've seen it all. 54 isn't that many for a game that's strictly multiplayer and has unlimited replay value, after all. It isn't a good thing, and I'll explain how and why. In short, the game is broken internally by mechanics that seek to disrupt the basic structure and mechanics of the game, and the devs break the game externally with lack of accessibility and utter garbage matchmaking.

Let us begin with a breakdown of the basic mechanics. The Killer is up against 4 Survivors who need to escape by repairing 5 of 7 generators around the map, and then open a door to the exit, of which there are 2. The Killer needs to injure and down the Survivors and carry them to hooks all around the map, where if they stay too long without a teammate unhooking them, they die. The Killer moves faster than the Survivors, but they can vault through windows and throw pallets down to stall/stun the Killer in order to try to escape. The Killer's presence is telegraphed in 2 ways: the terror radius, which is represented by a heartbeat sound playing for nearby Survivors, and the red stain, which illuminates the area immediately in front of the Killer so the Survivor can tell if the Killer is right behind them. Some Killers, however, can get rid of both of these warning factors because their abilities give them the undetectable status. Examples of this include the Pig, Shape, and Ghost Face. However, don't start thinking that Killers get the upper hand in games very often. Even with egregious perks such as barbeque & chili, which reveals all Survivors' locations whenever one of them is hooked, Survivors still get the advantage by default. Their perks include the likes of decisive strike and dead hard, which allow a Survivor to freely escape a Killer while being carried to a hook once and negate a hit from the Killer, respectively. Given that the game is all about time efficiency (having one Survivor stall the Killer in a chase while the rest repair generators is an example), the Survivors having access to perks that directly add time to the Killer's game take it over because there are 4 of them to the 1 Killer. On both sides, the basic mechanics of the game are shattered. The stealth mechanics of the Survivors mean nothing in the face of the Killer's perk options, and the mechanics meant to make the Killer powerful mean nothing due to free time-killers from the Survivors. This, of course, is a very rough run-down. There are flashlights to blind the Killers, mechanics that make the Killer down a Survivor in one hit rather than two, etc. Over time, the game has, by need of getting people to buy the DLC (OH! Did i mention that the vast majority of broken perks are stuck behind a pay wall?), broken itself in massive power creep.

Now let's move on to external breaking. Remember how I only have 54 hours? I bought the game last fall. I would theoretically have many more by now, but error codes prevented me from opening the game until recently, all of which the mods on the game's forums had no clue how to solve. Obviously, I wasn't the only one with the issues; the forums have many posts about the same error codes and issues I was having. Even in the game, however, there are still glaring issues, primarily with matchmaking. In this game, you start at rank 20 and work your way down to 1; in general, the lower your rank, the better and more experienced you are. If you ever try playing as a Killer, you'll immediately notice that you are constantly matched with players of much lower rank than you. For example, I've crawled my way to rank 12 as a Killer, yet along that journey, every game (not an exaggeration) I will be matched with players of rank 7 or lower, at least one, usually two, and three or four with more frequency than being matched with one. If only skill were different between low and middle/high rank players this wouldn't be as large of an issue, but since you have to unlock the broken perks that give you a chance in low rank games using points awarded based on your performance in games, the matchmaking traps the Killers in a never-ending cycle of getting bullied by low rank survivors and getting little to no points for it. On a similar but unrelated to matchmaking note, Survivors can get screwed out of a game by Killers spawning on top of them, which is purely luck-based, or by being 'tunneled' - targeted hard by Killers so that they die almost immediately if they don't play perfect to escape (which frequently gives the other Survivors the free win) - or camped on a hook. In addition, Survivors can stack up as a party to search for games (referred to as Survivor-with-friends or swf), and the highest rank player is used for matchmaking, meaning low rank Survivors can farm points off of high rank, inexperienced Killers.

So, should you buy this game? That's a rhetorical question.

Dead By Daylight is like a castle of cards that keeps crumbling on itself and keeps being rebuilt with duck tape.

It's a PvP game without a win condition, and this speaks for itself.
Since there is no clear win condition, the overall balance is decided around random opinions and community outcries.
Since there is no balance, the game is a mess and playing it literally feels like a coin toss.
And even if the coin toss lands on your side, you don't feel satisfied anyway because everybody has different goals.

On top of everything, it lacks basic game features and many design faults encourage toxicity as a side effect.

It's a horror party game disguised as a competitive game and if you take it seriously you should play something else.
Unless you like horror themes, in that case DBD is an excellent game that you should research on Wikipedia.

But the game itself is absolute trash and keeps on being played just because of effective marketing strategies and because it has no competition.

The developers have no idea what they're doing and unless someone with clear ideas rebuilds it from scratch, it will die as soon a working alternative gets released.
